article_title: In Senate race, Menéndez was Joe Straus in reverse
article_text:
In Senate race, Menéndez was Joe Straus in reverse

Six years ago, a coalition of 72 Democrats and 16 Republicans opened the door for Joe Straus to become speaker of the Texas House.

article_metadata.description: Republican participation in this race was not a case of butting into a Democratic contest to make mischief, a la Rush Limbaugh’s “Operation Chaos” call for Republicans to cross over in 2008 presidential primaries and sow Democratic discord by voting for Hillary Clinton.  Martinez Fischer had good reason to object to harsh TV ads from the Texans for Lawsuit Reform PAC, which mocked Martinez Fischer as a shameless ambulance chaser: “Having a bad day?” the voice-over narrator asked.  [...] Martinez Fischer ran a primary campaign in a non-primary election.  With the race slipping away, one of his support groups, the Texas Association of Consumer Lawyers PAC, even muddied up their own message with an 11th-hour push card — presumably encouraging conservative voters to stay home — showing that Menéndez and Martinez Fischer have identical progressive positions on state spending, the Affordable Care Act and abortion.
article_metadata.author.name: By Gilbert Garcia, Metro Columnist

og.description: Republican participation in this race was not a case of butting into a Democratic contest to make mischief, a la Rush Limbaugh’s “Operation Chaos” call for Republicans to cross over in 2008 presidential primaries and sow Democratic discord by voting for Hillary Clinton. [...] Martinez Fischer ran a primary campaign in a non-primary election.  With the race slipping away, one of his support groups, the Texas Association of Consumer Lawyers PAC, even muddied up their own message with an 11th-hour push card — presumably encouraging conservative voters to stay home — showing that Menéndez and Martinez Fischer have identical progressive positions on state spending, the Affordable Care Act and abortion.
